content.description: Good Old Fashioned LCC Slabbin'
content.location: Far Side

content.description: This problem starts low as and rightmost on the lip by a large tree root, on the boulder just left of Blue Steel when looking west, or down canyon. Start either with arms wrapped around the root (try not to dab), or for full value start scrunched with both arms right of the root. Traverse the full lip and mantle at the end. A very fun weird problem if you're in the area!
content.location: Start scrunched up near the tree root on the rightmost part of the boulder

content.description: Start on the left arete of the timber boulder matched on a big jug. Move up the arete and right to the apex of the boulder and top out. Smile, you just had fun, sort of. Refer to the image for the  intended route.
content.location: On the left arete of the Timber boulder.

content.description: Start with hands wide, left hand in sidepull and right-hand good edge. PUll on and move into the first crimp used for timber. Now move straight up the face on thin edges. Move up and right to finish it up. You climb over the boulder to the right, so take care not to blow the middle and top out moves. Refer to beta image for route intention.
content.protection: 1 pad and a blubber for the rock
content.location: On the same face as timber.

content.description: Start match on high edge to the right then go left and up. Top out either by pulling around the corner onto the slab or go straight up. Both feel about the same, going straight up is more exciting.
content.location: Follow the directions to Fool's Gold then go east for 20 yards. You cannot miss it

content.description: Amazing movement on a cool rail with a couple of surprisingly (huh huh!?) technical bits before you gain the arete start of Surprise, and then finish on that problem. Turns Surprise from a power/technical boulder into a bit more of a power endurance experience. Very nice!
content.protection: you'll want another pad to cover this - I had to use a high heel, and you can blow out of that kind of hard onto your back.
content.location: Start sitting down and right from the surprise arete, on the furthest right decent holds you can find. It's about 6 feet of climbing across into the arete, before heading up Surprise.

content.description: Climb straight up the face using only the face holds. Start on the rail, right hand up to undercling above head height, left hand to a slanted crimp, right hand to crystal and then exit on the top moves of surprise.
content.location: Direct line to Surprise

content.description: Start standing with right hand on the ramp and left hand at the same level on the arête. Work your way up the arête with dynamic moves followed by a perplexing top out over the bulging lip.
content.location: Located at the far (west) end of the Far Side.  Follow the climber's trail down canyon from the Buzz Boulders for a few hundred yards, passing some of the main Far Side boulders along the way. Surprise is a northwest facing overhanging arete with a juggy ramp extending to the right.

content.description: Start on Stacie's Arete, the traverse the lip and top out on Ringer
content.location:
Just uphill of Alzheimer's

Check out "Ringer" for the topo

content.description: Sit start on far left side of the boulder and climb the arete
content.location:
Just uphill from Alzheimer's

Check out "Ringer" for the topo

content.description: A tricky little problem, as eluded to by the name. It's a fun test of footwork and your ability to problem solve. Start sitting in the corner at the far right side of the boulder and use both sides of the wall to head up the seam and top out on the final slab.
content.location: Seems Easy can be found towards the end of the Farside trail, just before you reach the Surprise boulder. Follow the directions for getting to the Farside, then pass the highly clustered boulders containing problems like The Buzz and Alzheimer's. Eventually you will need to keep heading down and right, towards the stream. There is currently a fallen log across the trail which makes the point where the trail veers downhill easy to miss, and other trails have been worn in as a result but they will not take you as directly to Seems Easy and Surprise. Continue on for a few hundred feet and just before you reach the Surprise boulder, Seems Easy will appear on the large boulder to your right. Many other worthwhile problems exist on this block, from V0-V7.

content.description: Do the first move of Ringer and then mantle for the top out. Arete is off.
content.location: On the Ringer boulder just uphill of Alzheimers. Topo on the "Ringer" Page

content.description: Start with left hand crimp right hand sidepull. Make one move to the lip and top out
content.location: Just uphill from Alzheimers

content.description: A high quality slab with a couple gnarly moves to get established. Start on the two obvious crimps and climb straight up.
content.location: Just southeast of Alzheimer's. Climbs the middle of the obvious slab.

content.description:
A burly variation on the Pawn Stars boulder.

Start with the left hand undercling and right hand matched on the sloper gaston. Pull on and hit the right hand sloper on the lip, then bump up more slopers over the bulge.

Unsure on grade, anywhere from V8-V10 perhaps
content.location: Match on the undercling feature and go straight to the sloper. The holds to the right are off. Check out "Fool's Gold" for directions to the boulder.

content.description: Start with the left hand on sloper pinch and right hand on small sidepull crimp under the roof. Make one hard move and top out on Fools Gold
content.location: On the left side of the Fools Gold boulder. Check out Fools Gold for the topo.

content.description: Big/insecure move up right to a juggy rail.
content.location: Starts on a C shaped edge/flake about 5ft to the right of the NW arete on the west face of the far side boulder.

content.description: Weird first move to good edges and a weird top out.
content.location: North west arete of the Garth boulder. Start with right hand on the arete and left hand under the boulder. Stop the barn door to send.

content.description: This is an worthwhile, though not entirely pleasant, techy vert line on small churt holds. Worth doing if you climb harder than v5, so that this comes fairly quickly. You don't want to have to spend a lot of time on it. Also more worth it to do this if don't mind using a slick single pad crimp. The top out is a gritty rail that currently crumbles at the touch.
content.location:
Backside of alzheimers boulder. There is a backbone curling up and right. If you keep your feet below and on the right side of this blunt arete, and your hands grip over the lip of it, you are on Lucky.

If you climb to the left of it, and your feet are on the slabbier section to the left of the backbone, that's Luckier v2.

content.description: Sit start (bad low left sidepull, good RH crimp), gain good crimps and then hop to the huge jug up and right.
content.protection: 3 pads artfully balanced on the logs
content.location: Walk 50 yards uphill from the bridge, first big boulder on the left

content.description: On the face of timber starting in the offset. (see photo for start hands, circled in red). Start left hand on good pinch and right sloper/undercling, pull on and move right hand to sloper edge. Finish up as Timber.
content.location: On the same face as timber.

content.description: Sit start on good jug and move up to crimps and then deadpoint good jug on the lip to the right.
content.location: just uphill from Blue Steel, same start as Le Tigre

content.description: sit start on good jug, move up and left around arete.
content.location: Just uphill from blue steel

content.description:
Start on the jug for Jason V1.

From the Black Bible: "Variation: V3.  Head up the sidepull features on the right"

This was a really fun variation, so I felt it was worth putting on Mountain Project

Very thin and tall problem.

Start on the jugs about 5ft up and climb the slab.

The top out is a little scary hehe
content.location:
Located right in the middle of the main side of the boulder.

Walk down the back side of the boulder.

content.description: Crimpy boulder problem starting on the RHS of the "foot rail" for Surprise
content.location: On the arete to the right of Surprise

content.description:
Slopey arete then rock over the slab and tip toe up 8 feet of mossy, low angle slab.

Stand start might be of Garth's Roof.
content.location: Down the hill from Alzheimer's. On river side(North)of boulder.

content.description:
Compression roof moves to a very slopey arete then rock over the slab and tip toe up 8 feet of mossy, low angle slab.

Sit start with left hand under roof and right hand on the arete.  Squeeze the arete and flake to a decent hold on the arete. Throw a high heel, and negotiate the slopey arete- gunning for a nice rail at the base of the slab. Haul yourself over the lip, and enjoy some friction slab to the top.

Nice problem to work alone.  Stand start might be V4.
content.location: Down the hill from Alzheimer's.  On river side(North)of boulder.

content.description: RH on sidepull, LH on sloper/sidepull (at shoulder height ). Head up.
content.location: A few feet right of Alzheimer

content.description:
Start with left hand on slopy pinch and right hand around the arete. Figure out how to match the left hand start hold and go up.

Top is harder than it looks
content.protection: 2-3 pads. You'll want to pad the rock on the back just under the left hand start hold
content.location: Walk west on the Farside trail and take the first faint trail to the left about 10-20 yards after passing "Alzheimers" and "Dirty Tall". It's a little easy to missand it's not the one that goes straight uphill at "Dirty Tall. The trail will lead you uphill and west (diagonal) towards Fool's Gold.

content.description:
A neat slab climb with interesting moves. Stand start with left hand on the decent sloper rail and right on a two finger sidepull. Move straight up the face, bumping left hand up the rail and right to more crystals, aiming for the one good edge up high. Bad feet.

The left arete is a fun V2.

The face to the right is "Piece of Cake" V7

Let me know if this has been done before. Definitely between the lines but is fairly obvious.
content.location: On the slabby boulder you come to right before Alzheimer's. Climbs the north face, left of center, with the obvious sidepull rail.

content.description:
Not the best boulder, but it does exist. Safety goggles would be nice for all the flaking rock, dirt, and lichen heading for your eyeballs.

If it were clean, it would probably be very nice. The moves themselves, one can imagine, would be fun on clean rock.
content.location: From Alzheimer's, head down trail another 15 feet. Look left. You will see a dirty arete. Start on the right side of it, make a couple sketchy moves on lichen.

content.description:
This balancy low ball starts on two small crimps on the lower left side of the face. Move right staying below the rail and reach a low side crimp far out to the right (contrived, but fun!), then go for the jug on the far right to top out.

Mantle straight up without going out to the side crimp for a V3.
content.location: Located behind the Blue Steel boulder, about 50 yds SW of the bridge.

content.description: Climb the shallow dihedral feature just on the slight corner on the right side of the west face. When we did it, we started with right hand on the sidepull and left hand on the lower edge. A lower start would go, but it seemed pretty contrived.
content.protection: A few pads. There are rocks in the landing area.
content.location: The boulder is located near the end of the Far Side trail. Park at Riverside, follow the trail across the river passing The Buzz and Blue Steel and head west from there. This is the last boulder that you come to before reaching the Surprise boulder. Seems Easy is on the same boulder.

content.description: Short problem on slopers. Start left hand on a low sidepull, right hand on a decent sloper scoop. Fire up to the good sloper at the lip.
content.location: Small boulder off to the left as you take the main trail to Surprise.

content.description: Start on ramp and climb left arete to a delicate mantle. Technical crux is low.
content.protection: Beaver dam + Logs. People say the fall is safe, but I wouldn't want to test it.
content.location: Large boulder 20m down canyon from bridge, visible when crossing the river

content.description: Nice little mantel problem.
content.location: Located on the very left of the main side of the boulder.

content.description:
From BB: Start on a positive edge for the LH and a small sidepull for the RH. Hit the lip, then a weird move to gain the top.

V10 Sit Start. Jeff Webb FA'd both, even though he forgot.
content.location: On the trail, just past Brutus
